<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will take measurements of a stack of glass microscope slides to estimate the number of slides in the stack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 398, 135]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the stack of slides.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 144, 730, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 146, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
Measure the length \(l\), the width \(w\) and the height \(h\) of the stack of slides in centimetres to the nearest millimetre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 377, 499, 395]]<|/det|>
Do **not** remove any slides from the stack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 406, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 438, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
<form>w = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 469, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 486, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 516, 146, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 516, 180, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 516, 920, 550]]<|/det|>
Use the balance provided to measure the mass \(M\) of the stack of slides to the nearest \(0.1 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 561, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ....................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 562, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 594, 181, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 593, 920, 626]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the glass. Use your results from **(a)** and **(b)**(i) and the equation shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 636, 534, 664]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{M}{lwh}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 759, 440, 778]]<|/det|>
Give the unit for your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 790, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 821, 920, 839]]<|/det|>
<form>unit = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 836, 920, 855]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
The mass \(m\) and the thickness \(t\) of a single microscope slide are written on the piece of card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 601, 120]]<|/det|>
Write down the values of \(m\) and \(t\) that are on the card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ....................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<form>t = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 183, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
Use your answer to **(b)(i)** and information from the card in **(c)** to estimate the number of microscope slides \(N_{1}\) in the stack of slides.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 272, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
<form>N_{1} = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
Use your answer to **(a)** and information from the card in **(c)** to obtain another estimate of the number of microscope slides \(N_{2}\) in the stack of slides.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>N_{2} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 148, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 413, 920, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 870, 477]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 504, 507]]<|/det|>

calculation

statement ................................................................................................................. [2]

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a light-emitting diode (LED) when the current in it changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 593, 137]]<|/det|> The supervisor has set up the circuit as shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 147, 678, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 345, 532, 363]]<|/det|> [a] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 144, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 375, 339, 395]]<|/det|> • Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 868, 426]]<|/det|> Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{\mathrm{PQ}}\) across the \(220\Omega\) resistor in the top row of Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 336, 457]]<|/det|> • Open the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 438, 917, 457]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 469, 541, 488]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 873, 615]]<|/det|>
resistance between P and Q /Ω\(V_{\mathrm {PQ}}/.....\)\(V_{\mathrm {QR}}/.....\)\(I/.....\)\(R_{\mathrm {LED}}/\Omega\)
220
330
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 625, 148, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 625, 576, 644]]<|/det|> • Disconnect the voltmeter from points P and Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 740, 676]]<|/det|> • Reconnect the voltmeter across the LED between points Q and R. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 750, 707]]<|/det|> • Ensure that the positive terminal of the voltmeter is connected to Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 339, 738]]<|/det|> • Close the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 750, 658, 769]]<|/det|> Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{\mathrm {QR}}\) in the top row of Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 781, 336, 800]]<|/det|> • Open the switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 781, 920, 800]]<|/det|> [1]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 688, 91]]<|/det|>
Calculate the current \(I\) in the circuit in part (a) using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 98, 536, 128]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 146, 303, 164]]<|/det|>
where \(R = 220\Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 207, 547, 227]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 237, 690, 258]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 266, 551, 300]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 761, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the image formed by a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 260, 120]]<|/det|> Refer to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 128, 808, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 299, 533, 317]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 144, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 330, 358, 349]]<|/det|> Switch on the lamp. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 173, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 361, 920, 395]]<|/det|> Place the lens at a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object (the triangular hole in the card). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 408, 173, 427]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 408, 920, 441]]<|/det|> Adjust the position of the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|> Measure, to the nearest \(0.1 \text{cm}\), the image distance \(v\) from the centre of the lens to the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 616, 504]]<|/det|> Record the image distance \(v\) in the top row of Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 516, 541, 534]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 546, 798, 752]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 660, 89]]<|/det|>
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate at which the water cools depends upon the diameter of the water surface exposed to the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 304, 166]]<|/det|>
You are provided with:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 332, 198]]<|/det|>
· a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 479, 214]]<|/det|>
· a set of glass beakers of different sizes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 334, 229]]<|/det|>
· a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 566, 260]]<|/det|>
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 485, 291]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 292, 321]]<|/det|>
In your plan, include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 391, 352]]<|/det|>
· any other apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 918, 399]]<|/det|>
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 426, 431]]<|/det|>
· the key variables you will control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
· a results table to record your measurements (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 491, 608, 508]]<|/det|>
· how you will process your results to draw a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 510, 539]]<|/det|>
You may include a labelled diagram if you wish.
